comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: May 2, 1914 was declared "woman suffrage day" and parades and meetings were held in almost every state. See memory.loc.gov/ammem/collections/suffrage/nwp/brftime.html and NYT editorial from May 2, 1914 supporting the effort query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9C0DE2D9153AE733A... NYT of May 3, 1914 said "Suffrage Day is Widely Kept" on its front page. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9907EFD81E39E633A... continued at query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9A07EFD81E39E633A... which mentions Dr. D. M. Dunn as being in the same car as Mrs. James Lee Laidlaw. Washington Herald of May 3, 1914 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045433/1914-05-03/ed-... suggests that 2 million women marched in cities across the country. New-York Tribune of May 3, 1914 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1914-05-03/ed-...

comment.author: 11418107@N02
comment._content: Dr. D. M. Dunn was head of the women's department of the Life Extension Institute.  She also served on the executive committee of the German-American Suffrage Association in the 1910s.  Dunn was a proponent of moderate corseting, and regular exercise for women.

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: books.google.com/books?id=IohLAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA122&l... is a 1921 article by her in The Woman's Journal and books.google.com/books?id=U7A8AAAAMAAJ&pg=RA5-PA20&am... is another in The Literary Digest.

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: I see that the first two pictures that Wystan links to above are taken at the same spot as the picture of Dunn.  See the tree at right.  The first one includes the same banner -- which is consistent with the NYT reporting that Dunn and Laidlaw traveled in the same car.

comment.author: 13102246@N03
comment._content: was she a proponent of moderate corseting compared to heavy corseting, or a proponent of moderate corseting compared to no corseting at all? I would like to read opinion articles about this whole corseting issue! Where there questions at Congress?

comment.author: 11418107@N02
comment._content: Here's the link about her ideas on corseting (but to answer your question, both! She considered exercise important, but thought a well-made moderate "low" corset was preferable to no corset, if a woman had bad posture; but heavy, badly-made corsets were still harmful). Note that Dr. D. M. Dunn is referred to as "he" in the introduction to this article. books.google.com/books?id=U7A8AAAAMAAJ&pg=RA5-PA20&am...
